Summary Larry Heck joined Google Research in 2014 as a Machine Intelligence research scientist. From 2009-2014, he was with Microsoft. In 2009, he started the personal assistant effort in Microsoft's Speech Group. The effort established the early conversational understanding (CU) scientific foundations for Cortana, Microsoft’s personal assistant launched on Windows Phone in 2014. From 2005 to 2009, he was Vice President of Search & Advertising Sciences at Yahoo!, responsible for the creation, development, and deployment of the algorithms powering Yahoo! Search, Yahoo! Sponsored Search, Yahoo! Content Match, and Yahoo! display advertising. From 1998 to 2005, he was with Nuance Communications and served as Vice President of R&D, responsible for natural language processing, speech recognition, voice authentication, and text-to-speech synthesis technology. He began his career as a researcher at the Stanford Research Institute (1992-1998), initially in the field of acoustics and later in speech research with the Speech Technology and Research (STAR) Laboratory. Dr. Heck received the PhD in Electrical Engineering from the Georgia Institute of Technology in 1991. He has published over 80 scientific papers and has granted/filed for 47 patents. 
 
Specialties: natural language understanding and generation, dialog systems, speech and speaker recognition, speech synthesis, web search, online advertising, machine learning, pattern recognition, signal processing, acoustics, artificial intelligence. Labs August 2010  –  June 2012  (1 year 11 months) Santa Clara, CA I involve in multiple research projects at Yahoo!, and use technologies of Data Mining, Machine Learning, User Understanding, Anti-Abuse, Social Networks, and Hadoop on massive datasets.  
 
- Anti-Fraud: developed advanced machin learned anti-fraud models which help a major Asian E-commerce website to reduce the fraud rate of by 50% and reduce spending on a buyer protection program by 70%. We published 2 academic papers in CIKM and WWW. We also won a Yahoo! superstar team award, which is the highest achievement in the company. 
 
- User reputation and expertise: developed user reputation and expertise models which helps many Yahoo! properties to find the valuable contributors and fight the spammers and abusers. We published 1 paper in KDD and 1 paper in SIGIR. 
 
- Customer engagement and segmentation: why some users get more engaged and the other are less engaged? How to analyze their pattern and predict their future engagement? What is the reason for the change? I study those problem based on massive user activity data and build engagement and segmentation model to answer those questions. 
 
- Social networks and influence inferring: people share articles to their friends on social channels like Facebook, Twitter. I study the problem how to find the influential users and construct the affective social networks and interests networks based on the user interaction data. Data Scientist Intent Media Inc. August 2012  – Present (3 years 1 month) Greater New York City Area Intent Media is Adwords for E-commerce sites. We help e-commerce websites monetize their non-converting traffic through media. This requires modeling user behavior in real-time to understand buying habits/comparison shopping patterns. And here is where large-scale predictive analytics and statistical models come in.  
 
My role was soup to nuts data science - problem definition, prototyping statistical/machine learning model at scale, writing production code in collaboration with infrastructure/platform team, debugging models behaving badly. Along the way, also spent time on product analytics questions that helped understand the business, generate hypothesis, setup and analyze A-B tests. Rinse and repeat i.e. iterate on everything.

- Design and Development of Federated Search Algorithms ( going beyond "10 blue links" by integrated vertical content into search results )

Keywords: Machine Learning models, A/B testing, Auctions, Contextual bandits, Pig, Click log analysis, Revenue-Relevance-User experience optimization, Smart pricing, Federated Search Graduate Research Assistant Carnegie Mellon University June 2005  –  August 2007  (2 years 3 months) Greater Pittsburgh Area There are many things that make automatic speech processing - whether speech recognition or translation hard, and in fact harder than text. I worked on algorithmic modeling of 2 of these phenomenon: 
 
1) Disfluencies - the corrections, repetitions and fillers 
2) Sentence segmentation - human tendency to not speak in bursts/segments rather than complete sentences with well-demarcated boundaries.  
 
This work that improved quality of machine translation was a part of the CMU GALE Speech Translation System (a DARPA project) Research Assistant Indian Institute of Science July 2003  –  June 2004  (1 year) 10 second version: 
 
Worked on the design and development of speech enhancement algorithms.  
--  
 
The 1 minute version: 
 
My love for Digital Signal Processing took me to IISC working on speech enhancement i.e. denoising of speech. This is where I learnt how to do academic research - starting from survey of prior work, reading research papers, actually doing the research and communicating research ideas through technical publications.  
 
I published in 2 major speech conferences - ICASSP and ICSLP - with my advisor Dr. T.V. Sreenivas.  
 
It was here that realized that much of work in speech (and since then other fields) was in statistical modeling algorithms rather than speech signal representation (signal processing aspect). This was a precursor to my future work. Summary I lead the science team responsible for maintaining and enriching the Yahoo Knowledge Graph, a large unified knowledge graph that provides rich information about entities and powers a wide variety of entity-based services at Yahoo.

I held several other R&D positions at startups and large organizations, including research engineer at Yahoo Labs, Web search engineer at Yahoo, team lead at Kelkoo, teaching and research assistant at the University of Rennes, and research engineer at Orange Labs. - Information extraction from heterogeneous data sources on the Web 
- Ontology alignment, schema mapping, and data normalization 
- Integration and knowledge management: e.g. entity deduplication, fusion, type inference

Env.: Linux, Hadoop/Pig/Java, Spark/Scala, Python, Git, Protege, Graph databases, ... Senior Research Engineer Yahoo Labs January 2009  –  March 2013  (4 years 3 months) San Francisco Bay Area Involved in several Information Extraction and Knowledge Management projects for Yahoo. 
 
1) Information Extraction 
Designed and implemented a system that continuously extracted and normalized entities and relationships from Wikipedia and misc. data sources on the Web. Resulting entity-relationship graph (7M entities ; 450M relationships) powered semantic search and content analysis projects at Yahoo. 
 
2) Knowledge Representation and Knowledge Engineering 
Key contributor to the WOO ontology, a large OWL ontology for representing information about entities at Yahoo. Also designed an ETL system based on XML/XSLT for doing large-scale schema mapping and data normalization in a distributed fashion, declaratively. 
 
3) Information Integration and Knowledge Management 
Contributed to WOO, a large-scale information integration platform for deduping entities coming from several sources, and drove the Yahoo Knowledge Base project, which used WOO to build the first centralized knowledge base of all the entities and relationships we cared about at Yahoo. 
 
4) Semantic Search  
Developed graph mining algorithms and systems to add Semantic Search capabilities to Yahoo Search (e.g. faceted search, related entities, etc.) 
 
5) Text Mining 
Developed a system for extracting and ranking interesting snippets from user-generated reviews

Information Extraction, Web Search, Web/Graph Mining, Content Analysis 
 
Developed a system for extracting and normalizing entities and relationships from feeds and structured data on the Web. This system enriched several dictionaries and knowledge bases within Yahoo! Search, which were used for Content Analysis and Query Interpretation. 
 
Worked on a knowledge-based system that automatically builds large semantic graphs from feeds and Web Search results using Web Mining techniques. Also worked on mining and ranking these semantic graphs for categorizing terms and finding related terms. This system was used on Yahoo! Sport, and has been evaluated on Yahoo! Search and Yahoo! Led the refactoring of a content analysis system that performs key term extraction from Web documents and returns weighted term vectors. Also worked on enriching the results of this system with related terms coming from the knowledge-based search system we developed.

June 2010  – Present (5 years 3 months) Mountain View, CA I have been working on Product Nouns Recognition and Attributes Extraction in the backend-team at TheFind. Advanced Machine Learning and NLP techniques are applied to these problems on a large scale. Based on the information from our index data, tens of thousands of products nouns have been identified and hundreds of thousands of attributes have been recognized for these nouns. More specifically,  
•	Designed and implemented product nouns recognition pipeline. It identifies the proper product noun from the title and description of a product. The goal is achieved by applying different techniques adapted from natural language processing and machine learning areas.  
•	Designed and implemented product attributes extraction pipeline. The ultimate goal of the attribute project is to have a complete list of attributes (along with all the possible values of each attribute) for each noun. Then based on such comprehensive information, given a product, we have successfully recognized many attributes for each product by applying various information extraction techniques. After the attributes of a product properly identified, we have a better idea of what the product is and improved noun recognition, text classification, indexing and search relevancy. Expertise: C/C++, Core-JAVA, Hadoop (PIG) Experience Principal Member of Technical Staff Oracle July 2012  – Present (3 years 2 months) Pune I am working as part of InnoDB Group (MySQL) at Oracle developing features of InnoDB (database kernel internals). 
 
InnoDB is now a default Storage Engine of MySQL and one of the widely used SE in open-source community. I have been mainly concentrating on temporary table and related feature. In last few years MySQL is revamping this to make it super-fast and light-weight. 
 
In process to reach the mark I have worked on significant improvement right from separate tablespace for temp-tables, improvement in undo-logs of temp-tables, replacing the default MyISAM SE with InnoDB SE (with performance better than MyISAM something that was assumed to be unachievable to start with). 
 
Besides this has worked extensively on other parts of InnoDB: making truncate atomic for tablespace, undo-tablespace truncate, elevating overall performance through fixes in different area. 
 
In upcoming days I will be focusing on inmemory option of InnoDB. Senior Research Engineer Yahoo! Labs May 2010  –  July 2012  (2 years 3 months) Bangalore My research mainly involved in extracting userful information from tons of the data that Yahoo! crawls or obtain from different providers. 
 
I was working as part of Extraction Group where-in idea was to build algorithmic pipeline to extract data directly from crawled information. This extracted data can either help in enriching existing algorithm (ad-serving for example) or help generate a data-feed (Y! Local).

- Finding Official Home Page of Business (Restaurant, Clinic, etc...)

Software Engineer Cisco Systems (through Persistent) January 2006  –  August 2006  (8 months) Pune Application Oriented Networking (AON) Solution - Event Management System. (http://www.cisco.com) 
 
Persistent System has worked with Cisco Systems, Inc. for development of an event management system for one of their crucial solution classified under AON (Intelligent Message Routing System). AON boxes are deployed just prior to an Application Server so that all the incoming-outgoing traffic can be scanned. AON boxes relieve Application Server from out-of-band functionality like message parsing, verifying security and triggering rules for validation of condition. This increase Application Server throughput + enhances security. AON boxes carry out above-mentioned activities in faster fashion as most of the things execute in embedded hardware. Event Management play a crucial role in this system by making sure that all the events generated by incoming-outgoing scanner module get directed in appropriate and timely fashion to the subscriber. 
 
Languages/Platforms Supported: JAVA 
Challenges:  
-	Very high throughput considering large number of events 
-	Multi condition subscriber model. 
 
Responsibilities:  
-	Defining Functional Specifications for Event Management System. 
-	Design of complete Event Management System. 
-	Development of some crucial components: Subscription Manager that support multi-conditional subscriber, Remote Request Acceptor and Central Event Manager.  
-	Implementation of Event Publisher library. 
-	Other allied activities like guiding other team members (technical lead) with technical inputs, local repository management. -	Acceptance test suite design and implementation to compare Rouge Wave’s implementation with library developed by Persistent Systems Software Engineer Informatica (through Persistent) September 2003  –  March 2004  (7 months) Pune Disk-backed dictionary for Informatica Corporation (http://www.informatica.com) 
 
Persistent Systems has developed a performance-driven library for disk-backed dictionary (B+ Tree on disk). The disk-backed dictionary is a critical and most important component of the Informatica PowerCenter® product transformations. The library has replaced RougeWave Btree library with significant performance improvements. It has full support for internationalization and no restriction on the type of the keys and data that can be inserted into the dictionary. 
 
Language/Platforms Supported: C++ on Windows 2000, Sun Solaris, AIX, HPUX, Linux 
Challenges:  
-	Flexibility to work with any type of data/keys  
-	Fast insertion/update/lookup beating the existing library performance by at least 2x 
-	Minimization in the blocked synchronous disk IO using “asynchronous IO” and also height of the tree for fast lookups using prefix tree compression techniques. 
-	Efficient Caching mechanism to minimize the IO 
 
Responsibilities:  
-	Prototyping of “asynchronous IO” in CacheManger to prove significant gains in IO performance as compared to blocking IO operation 
-	Development of asynchronous IO support into library for all platforms 
-	Design and development of Cache Manager

Summary I am currently a staff software engineer at Google, working on improving our world class ad technology. 
 
Prior to joining Google, I was a director of applied sciences in Yahoo! Labs' Search and Media Sciences division. I ran the Context Understanding and Page Optimization team which focuses on various research aspects of algorithmic page construction, including federated search, as well as applications of statistical natural language processing to user intent understanding. 
 
Prior to joining Yahoo in 2005, I spent most of my career in the field of speech recognition. I was a speech research scientist at Nortel's Bell Northern Research from 1994 through 1999 and then at Nuance from 1999 to 2005, where I worked mainly on acoustic modeling and efficient search algorithms.
